prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement, even though the basement would have been quieter. The wife has to manage the kids and housework, and his setup is causing her a lot of stress. She told him that if he stays in the bedroom, she can't promise him silence, which led to a fight.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband's job is mostly conference calls, so he needs a quiet environment. He chose the bedroom because he likes the view, which might be a personal preference. On the other hand, the wife is handling most of the household duties and her work from home. By setting up in the bedroom, he's making it hard for her to do her tasks because the whole top floor is off-limits when he's on calls. The basement option would have been better for both, but he didn't choose that.

The key points here are about shared space and mutual respect. The husband's choice affects the wife's ability to function. She suggested the basement, which seems like the logical choice for minimal disruption. By not moving his office there, he's causing conflict. The wife's response was to set boundaries, which makes sense because she can't control the kids or other household activities if he's in the bedroom. 

I think the husband is in a bit of a position where he's prioritizing his comfort over the practicality that affects his wife. The wife isn't wrong for setting boundaries when he's in the bedroom. She's handling a lot, and his choice is making it harder for her. So, the author (wife) isn't in the wrong. The answer should be B.
